title: A Beginner's Guide to Sending Documents to an Amazon Kindle Device

steps.title: Upload the document to the Send to Kindle Amazon page.
steps.content: Upload the document to the Send to Kindle Amazon page . Open the web page and log in to your Amazon account. Find the document you want to send on your computer and drop it into the center of the page to upload it. [1] X Research source Send to Kindle supports PDF, DOC, DOCX, TXT, RTF, HTM, HTML, PNG, GIF, JPG, JPEG, BMP, and EPUB files that are 200 MB or smaller. As of November 2023, Amazon Kindle no longer supports MOBI files. [2] X Research source Instead of visiting the website, download the desktop PC or Mac app .

steps.title: Select “Add to Library” to access the doc from any registered Kindle.
steps.content: Select “Add to Library” to access the doc from any registered Kindle. Once your document uploads, a small checkbox will appear. If you have multiple Kindles attached to your account and want to access the document on any of them, check the box. [3] X Research source If you don’t select “Add to Library,” a list of all the Kindle devices registered to your account will appear so you can pick which ones to send the file to.

steps.title: Click the Send button to transfer the file to your Kindle.
steps.content: Click the Send button to transfer the file to your Kindle. Make sure your Kindle is connected to wifi, and tap Sync in the device settings. It may take a few minutes for your document to transfer over to your Kindle.

steps.title: Add your email to the approved senders list on your Amazon account.
steps.content: Add your email to the approved senders list on your Amazon account. Log into your Amazon account and open the Content and Device Preferences page . Under the “Personal Document Settings” heading, add your email address to the Approved Personal Document Email List. [4] X Research source If you want to save documents to your Kindle library to access on all of your devices, turn on the Personal Document Archiving option from the Preferences menu.

steps.title: Locate your Kindle’s email address in the device settings.
steps.content: Locate your Kindle’s email address in the device settings. Open the settings on your Kindle and look under your Account information for the Send-to-Kindle email address. Alternatively, all of the Kindle email addresses are listed on the Preferences page for your Content and Devices. If you have multiple Kindle devices on your account, you can edit their individual email addresses so they’re easier to remember.

steps.title: Send an email with the document attached to your Kindle.
steps.content: Send an email with the document attached to your Kindle. Log in to the email account you added to the approved senders list. Type in your Kindle’s email address and add your document as an attachment. After that, just hit send to transfer the file over. [5] X Research source You don’t need to add a subject or any body text to the email. Emailing your Kindle supports PDF, DOC, DOCX, TXT, RTF, HTM, HTML, PNG, GIF, JPG, JPEG, BMP, and EPUB files. If you want to convert a PDF into a Kindle document that you can highlight and annotate, add “Convert” to the subject line before sending.

steps.title: Sync your Kindle with wifi to download the document on your device.
steps.content: Sync your Kindle with wifi to download the document on your device. Make sure to connect your Kindle to wifi and give it a few minutes to update. If your document doesn’t automatically download onto your Kindle within a few minutes, hit the Sync button on your Kindle to manually refresh it. You may receive an email from Amazon verifying that you sent a document to your Kindle. If you do, click on “Verify Request” to add the document to your Amazon library.

steps.title: Upload files from your phone to the Kindle app.
steps.content: Upload files from your phone to the Kindle app. Whether you’re using Android or iPhone, download the Kindle app and log in. Find the document on your phone and click on the Share icon. Select Kindle from the list of options, and the file will immediately load in on the app. [6] X Research source You can add PDF, DOC, DOCX, HTM, HTML, PNG, GIF, JPG, JPEG, BMP, and EPUB files to the Kindle app from your phone.

steps.title: Send Microsoft Word docs to Kindle with the Share feature.
steps.content: Send Microsoft Word docs to Kindle with the Share feature. From Microsoft Word, go to File in the menu, select Share from the dropdown, and click on Send to Kindle. From there you may choose to keep the formatting like a printed document or convert it to read like a Kindle book. [7] X Research source If you’re using the web version of Microsoft Word, then select Export and “Send documents to Kindle” from the File Menu.

steps.title: Share web pages to your Kindle with a Chrome browser extension.
steps.content: Share web pages to your Kindle with a Chrome browser extension . If you want to read a webpage more easily on your Kindle, install the Send to Kindle extension on your Google Chrome browser. Open the page you want to share and tap on the extension icon. Select “Quick Send” to share the entire page to your Kindle. [8] X Research source If you only want to send a portion of the page to your Kindle, highlight the text and select “Send Selection” instead. While there are no official Amazon extensions for other browsers, you may be able to find third-party extensions to send documents to your Kindle.

steps.title: Plug your Kindle in with a USB cord to manually drag and drop files.
steps.content: Plug your Kindle in with a USB cord to manually drag and drop files. If you’re not able to send documents wirelessly, connect your Kindle to your computer. When your Kindle appears as a device, open it and select the Documents folder. Move any files you want to add into the Documents folder to transfer them to your Kindle. [9] X Research source
